pros: Excellent working environment that is satisfactory
cons: You must be a very patient individual

pros: The only pros there is two weeks induction
cons: It’s about working experience in the specific project, 130 Loughor Road in Gorseinon, Swansea. Majority of staff behave like servants and clowns. No personal space with service users expressing challenging behaviour. Instead, hugging and cuddling with them… then staff receiving regular verbal and physical assaults from them. Staff who don’t perform such cuddling clowning behaviour is accused of creating tension and then quickly removed from the company . Staff forced to drive with challenging clients without any safety measures in place… risking being physically attacked during driving and causing potential serious accident. Any incidents reports are swept under the rug, without taking any action. Under-qualified management promoting own friends without any experience and qualifications in Healthcare. Instead the idea is the more cuddles you provide, then higher you can climb. No respect from management for other views and ideas regarding safety… instead, getting rid of such staff members. No allocated lunch breaks for staff, even on long shifts. Lots of racism abuse from service users towards staff of different nationalities and skin colour. No designated toilet facilities for staff… only shared with service users. Hiding many crucial information from applicants during interview, regarding extremely challenging behaviour and obligation to do sleeps at work between long shifts. Refusing the idea of flexible, fixed shifts patterns to support staff family life. Incredibly badly managed and dirty, falling apart place… disgusting to work at.

job_title: Community Support Worker in West Bromwich, England
pros: The PWS. Colleagues who care and actually turn up for work.
cons: Management. Low pay. Sleep-in rate is below most other companies. Staff constantly swapping and changing shifts.

review_title: Well run organization, very flexible and dignified managment in Bournemouth
pros: I always feel valued at Dimensions in the BCP area. Company culture is very open and accomodating, regular monthly one to ones provide an outlet to speak your mind and discuss how you're integrating/problems. Managers treat you very respectfully and there are not so many pressures as for profit care companies. Lots of opportunities for career progression.
cons: Pay is not the best, probably mid-range in the care sector.

pros: Helping the community knowing that you’re doing more than most
cons: Exploited by staff, over worked, poor working conditions

pros: Good benefits, nice colleagues / peers
cons: Career supports depends who your manager is

review_title: Rewarding, but physically and mentally taxing for the pay
job_title: Support Worker in Theale, South East England, England
pros: Really lovely to meet residents and socialise with them. Encouraging their independence makes you patient and happy to see them make progress
cons: Pay is too low for the work you do, very mentally draining

job_title: IT Helpdesk Support in Theale, South East England, England
pros: Nice colleagues Work from home Nice office-Theale The colleagues are friendly and there for you
cons: The top management The pay rise can be better given the fact that people work from home and the company makes tons of money...

review_title: Better than other companies but still rubbish
job_title: Support Worker in Weymouth, Dorset, South West England, England
pros: Good pay Nice people Hours if you need them
cons: Everything gets swept under a rug. One rule for one person one for another If you get injured at work and have to be off you won't get paid for it!!! They employ underperforming managers and teams have to 'pay' for it by getting their rotas week in advance, having their hours changed without discussion and many other bad managerial behaviours I've seen in my 2 years of service. Applied for driving with 3 different managers and Never heard back even though its been approved People are in toil due to managers not giving them their contracted hours Hard to get through to IT even though all of the recording is done online and all of our documents are online and no one else will help you. It's about who you know not what you know, witnessed manager paying double rate to a school friend for working around Christmas,no one else got it. That person would get payed waking night for sleep in but others wouldn't get asked to work overtime etc. So much stuff! For better picture I've worked under 3 different managers and long term it all happened in one house..

pros: Working from home, great valued company that provides support to colleagues when needed and always support by my manager. Worked within the company for over 5 years.
cons: Our support workers need more pay. Hiring of agency project managers does not work.

pros: It is a great place to work because everyone is friendly, open and genuine. The senior leaders and management are also very helpful.
cons: It can be hard having a good work life balance. The hours are sometimes long and tasks can be repetitive.

cons: Poor communication with team leaders, no standard procedures to follow

cons: Management insistent on staff to do sleep-in and long days which can lead to burnout

review_title: Dimensions is a flexible, professional and supportive service centred around not only
pros: Dimensions is a modern flexible and holistic service centred not only around providing the best level of care for the person you are supporting but involving the team in regular reviews of the care and developing you to be secure in your role by providing an extensive training scheme and fantastic opportunities to develop not only professional practice but personal goals too.
cons: When starting your journey with Dimensions, it is likely that you may initially become overwhelmed by the scale of the service and teams operating. The progress of the service is recorded digitally including communication and updates. You will quickly see the benefits of working this way- but it is best to enter Dimensions with an open mind and take on information at a pace that suits you. There is always someone available to seek advice and guidance at any time if needed.

pros: Flexible shifts, fair pay for the work done
cons: Long shifts in certain services

pros: Working for a values based organisation is really rewarding. You don't only get job satisfaction of helping others to achieve, but you get the support to upskill and develop within your own personal career. I absolutely love my job and would highly recommend Dimensions to anyone who shares our values.
cons: There are so many myths about social care which is putting increased pressure on the care sector. I would highly recommend doing research or speaking to someone about the role before coming to any conclusions.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Lincoln, England
pros: Dimensions care and support are understanding to both the people they support needs and their staff. I personally have experienced seeing this company put 'Care' at the top of their priorities. They support staff well and the happiness of the people they support is their priority, providing consistency and Dimensions are the best service provider for their ethics I have ever had the privilege to work for.
cons: I cannot think of any cons at this time. I have worked for Dimensions for almost 3 years.

pros: the team work well together and cross teams its like a huge family network

pros:
Sharing the day and night with the people I support is feels like being with "family". It's been such fun supporting the activities and daily schedule of the home. We have some laughs along the way. 
The other staff members are very helpful to me as a new employee. I feel reassured by the procedures that everyone in the home is well looked after and also look out for each other.
cons: Do check that Sleep-Ins are paid in line with HMRC expectation that 'employees are paid in accordance with the law on "minimum wage".'

job_title: Care Worker in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros:
Flexible working hours. 
Chance for training.
Opportunities to do activities during work.
However there was very few pros when working for this company.
cons:
Hours were long and rigid at terrible times despite being flexible, for example 7am-2pm or 2pm-9pm or overnight. 
Wages were awful for work expected. 
The training was poor and wasn’t offered for months until whistleblown. 
Work was physical strenuous and no physical therapy offered, along with no manual handling training. 
Communication was poor. 
And I was left on my own to work with agency staff after a week of working in my setting with no training.

job_title: Data Security Administrator in Newbury, England
pros: I have only been working at Dimensions for around 2+ months but I am enjoying it so far. Management are supportive and easy to approach and I feel like the company genuinely cares about the people they support. The online training is also helpful and interesting and weekly bulletins and messages from CEO are great to keep up to date. I feel Dimensions are inclusive and diverse.
cons: I do not have any cons to add to this review

job_title: Behavioural Support Practitioner in Sheffield, England
pros: Really excellent recruitment team, asked what I wanted throughout the process, a first in all of my applications. Excellent support from the immediate clinical team and wider clinical team. Good training, even without being able to go into an office environment.
cons: Not the most competitive pay, although to be expected from a not for profit. Some of the departments seem fairly disjointed compared with each other.

job_title: Human Resources Officer in London, England
pros: Its a great place to work. The values of this organisation is something we all live by, and those values stretch to people we support and staff. I've always been treated well, and have had a wedding, baby and bereavement during my time here. Through all of that, Dimensions have been more than good to me. I love my everyday job here, the people I work with have good values, and they're friendly and helpful. They have also been very flexible with me (especially when I became a new mum) and I honestly dont have anything bad to say about them. I highly recommend and dont see myself leaving at any point.
cons: I've thought long and hard about this, but couldn't think of anything. My experience has been amazing, and rewarding.

review_title: Poor management and treating people unfairly and not according to Human Right's 2010 Act
pros:
Not a lot, to be honest. Working hours 9 times out of 10 are not even agreed with the employees, very rude and dissatisfied managers, that only judge you and don't even give positive feedback.
I did like a few of my fellow colleagues, that was nice and did know I was doing my job right.
But management and 'lack of budget' would always get in a way.
Lack of empathy and understanding and lack of morale down here in Dorset is something unimaginable. The women there (almost all the managers are female by the way) became proper feminist and critics towards all their staff.
cons: Nothing much. The employee assistance programme was rubbish, nowhere near as good as advertised. Once you try to get a higher up position - bet of luck, because people don't want you to progress. The NVQ itself took the over a year to sign people up, for some they were never even offered in over 5 years! The training was mostly online that's why inadequate and poorly managed classroom-based trainings, as they have proven to be ineffective.

pros: Great manager, work at your own pace, support lovely people
cons: Workplace politics, low pay and long hours

pros: Very good training. Management and other staff are supportive. Extra pay for sleep over shifts.
cons: Higher level of personal care required than described in job advert.

cons: I don't have any cons

pros:
Wonderful clients
Other support staff are amazing and more helpful than actual management. 
Training for staff is the only benefit you will see. 
Stick it out for a
cons:
Poor pay, no breaks unless you smoke, will earn just over £1000 on full time hours + overtime.   
Dreadful management- condescending and unapproachable.
Management is lazy and expect support staff to do their job for them instead of supporting the clients.
When support staff do organise events for seasonal and charity events the management take all credit. Not even crediting staff in house or in office. Brings you to the next point of you don't feel like you are a worthy member of staff from the managements perspective because of the lack of praise. 
Lack of organisation and filtering of information down to lower levels lead to tensions and misinformation between families and staff
Box ticking approach rather than the person centred. 
The interviews and job description do not match to what the role entails. So lies from managers and HR from the get go is obviously going to lead to a high turnover of staff, as this is not what they were told to expect.

job_title: Support Worker in Watford, East of England, England
pros:
Supporting vulnerable people and making a difference.
Having full days off has its benefits.
Sleeping over helped to fit work around studies.
cons:
Low pay for the responsibilities.
Sleeping in 2 to 3 days a week has a big impact on personal/social life.
Management always busy and ”overstretched” and getting basic things like new diaries seemed like too much to ask.
Bit of a blame culture.
Very understaffed and support workers expected to cover their shifts, and in some cases, find cover for other people’s with little to no help from management (not my problem attitude).
If you're sick one day and can’t come in, you don't get paid.

pros: Some great support workers and service users. Opportunities to improve their quality of life, and support them to try new things. Rewarding to see their achievements.
cons: No support from management , no training apart from mandatory, a "them and us" culture by management, management do what they like and don't follow their own guidelines. If you want to be just another payroll number and be easily replaced - take a job here.

pros:
Still got a job of sorts
Less complicated policies
Yet to find out
Struggling to find anything to feel positive about if I am honest
cons:
Somerset Clounty Council LD services are being over by dimensions and we have been told tgat our contract terms and conditions & wages are to be slashed.
We have been misled throughout this process and now feel not valued at all
Relief staff wages have been cut and we rely on our relief staff, this on it's own will through us into crisis

review_title: Good Intention, shocking culture and leadership
job_title: in Theale, South West England, England
pros: Does some great things for the People it Supports and offers on job training
cons:
Dimensions Executive management lacks basic common sense and has instilled a blame culture across the business. Bullying and harassment is rife throughout the central office and is accepted. Challenging or offering a different viewpoint are frowned upon and in places punishable.

Zero strategy and conflicting egos mean that the clique of senior execs is allowed to rule without accountability. This is one of the worst places for political and egotistical leadership I have ever worked. They do not have the best interests of the business at their core and certainly do not live the values which are plastered on the walls.

Money is wasted in a not for profit organisation at a rate that would scare anyone, yet no one is held accountable.

review_title: Swanky head office vs out in the fields
job_title: Finance Assistant in Theale, South East England, England
pros: Never ceased to amaze me the hypocrisy of how well head office staff are looked after but out in the fields where people are supposed to be supported there is less to go around
cons:
Truly hypocritical exec and board team lining their pockets at the expense of those who need to be supported. This charity is supposed to be able helping people with autism learning disabilities etc and it does to a degree but only after pampering head office esp exec and board team.

People would be much better supported if they cut out and cut down the excesses of the fat cats. Particularly the chief executive, md, cfo and chairman are all hypocrites.

job_title: Community Support Worker in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Keen on keeping staff trained and they also take care of staff who put the effort into their work.

Learnt a lot over the past 4 years.

Support and career development with their Aspire programme.
cons:
Management has changed a lot over the past few years and things can often be very disorganised. But this is down to line managers. 

Be prepared to work a lot of hours. Which might not be a problem for some... But for the responsibility you have the pay is not worth it. 

Very under staffed. Sometimes pressured into working a lot of over time, often you don't have a choice.

IT support needs improving.

review_title: Brilliant company, fantastic team and great atmosphere
job_title: Head Office in Theale, South West England, England
pros: There are too many pros to list; this is one of the best companies I have worked for. The head office is located at Arlington Business Park which allows you to have access to a restaurant, gym, beauty salon etc. Everybody at head office is friendly and will always go out of their way to talk to you. Teams often take part in events, Halloween, coffee mornings, shoe box appeal, charity days etc.  Management are always friendly and approachable and will always support and encourage you to progress in your role.
cons: No cons I can think of

review_title: Suffers from the same issues as most care organisations
pros:
This is a very professional looking organisation
Very good online training
Permanent staff are very nice
cons:
Too many agency staff covering lack of resources
Pay does not recognise when extra duties are taken on
Claim to be flexible but actually use standardised shift patterns that are not always appropriate

review_title: A Charity Run by Incapable Boneheads
job_title: Internaltional String Consultant in Sheffield, England
pros: Great Staff who are incredibly patient
cons: Buffoons for management. Incompetant and under the table decisions made too frequently

job_title: Consultant Behaviour Analyst in Birmingham, England
pros:
A lot of support for career development (free BCBA supervision) you are able to keep up to date with legislation (e.g. DoLs) and best practice (ABAF, independent supervision as part of normal working hours).

The head of behaviour support is knowledge and able to give practical advice.
The whole behaviour support team are very approachable.

There is emphasis given on career development and interest given to external projects you might be working on (such as publishing papers).

You often see upper management come into services.

There are alot of platforms given to the people being supported a voice and some good events (disco, parties, sports day, cookery classes) which help the people we support network, gain skills and socialise.

Dimensions is a company that gives its employees a chance to work there way up (support workers become assistants, become managers etc), there are many departments (IT, HR, housing, PR) which peoples career can blossom in.

Theres are alot of benefits such as the employee assistance programme, sickness incentive bonus, Aspire programme.

Dimensions is a not for profit and puts its surplus back into the company and employees (yearly cash bonus in May if the company reaches its target).

There's never a dull moment, but that also means that you need to be able to demonstrate the core values (integrity, courage, ambition, respect, partnership) at all times.

The role requires you to be able to keep on top of alot of critical matters at once, Dimensions systems and support network help you to do this effectively.

I've always had regular one2ones and my manager always responds promptly and professionally.

Since being at Dimensions, amongst other things, I have become a Proact-scipr-uk Instructor, run a drop in clinic at the autism show and meet some extremely dedicated people.

I am looking forward to what is next at my career in Dimensions. I've been working here for 2 year and hope to be here for a lot more
cons: With the positives there are times where you can be in emotionally challenging situations (however there are good support networks) and there is alot of driving in my role (this is typically for behaviour analysts)

review_title: Poorly organised, Staff are not valued
pros:
The people we support
The staff team
cons:
-Managers can't seem to organise themselves, delegate jobs to people who either don't want them or let the power go to their head.
-Too much beaureacracy, policy and paperwork purely for making the company look good, not for the benefit of the people we support.
-Don't value staff, understaffed, take a long time to recruit, resulting in long hours.
-Pressure and blame staff for being late with training, documents required, etc, when management action is required to get some things started

review_title: Think Social Care, Think Job Satisfaction
job_title: Data Security Lead in Reading, England
pros: Values run through Dimensions, you feel the Respect, Integrity,  and Partnership, as soon as you enter and talk to anyone even at interview stage.  Once you arrive and you realise that everyone whatever their role is their for the people we support & the partnership across our roles is so strong.
cons: We have lots to do and we need to focus on many opportunities, so think out of the box and agile & you will enjoy the challenges.

pros: There is a lot of support within Dimensions and the company offers some great development opportunities. Although I am based in the office I do get to spend a lot of time with in the homes where the fantastic people we support live. Office staff are often encouraged to visit the homes of the people we support.
cons: The pay could be a bit better but ultimately the organisation is a non-for-profit so I understand why it is a bit lower.

job_title: Lead Resourcing Consultant in Reading, England
pros: Great organisation to work for. Friendly team and supportive manager.  The Aspire programme is also really useful and the level of training provided is endless. Dimensions is person centre and gives everybody a chance to voice their opinion. I love hearing about the impact we have and the difference we making to others lives.
cons: The only thing I would ask for is an increase in salary. - But I think this would be the case in most organisations.

job_title: Learning and Development Coordinator in Theale, South East England, England
pros: Very supportive systems in place, fun place to work.  Very organised.  Honest.  Sticks to its core values.  People really get on with each other in most cases.  People work towards a consistant team and goal.
cons:
Can be a little tricky for career progression without changing departments but there are supportive programmes you can enroll on to help with this.
Turnover can be quite high in teams requiring you to re-train/re-teach people the same skills multiple times

job_title: Senior Support Worker in Slough, Berkshire, South East England, England
pros: Lack of knowledge about learning difficulties or Autism syndrome. Challenging behaviour aspect describing as a cup of tea on the sofa, no schedules to burn energy and decrees outbursts.  No understanding of complex syndromes. Good points. Elderly care, good knowledge of Dementia, Alzheimer,  good day centers.
cons: Staff rotation,  constantly new staff

pros: The people we support are amazing
cons: The manager's don't care about staff or the people we support. Report a problem and it is ignored until something happens. Management don't care about safeguarding and claim credit for the hard work you put in. Pay is poor but will be in this sector.

job_title: Data Analyst in Theale, South East England, England
pros:
Kind and genuine staff at lower levels in the organisational hierarchy, doing their best with limited resources. A couple of standout co-workers, who go over and above expectations, but that sadly do not get the pay, recognition and respect they deserve.

They offer flexible working (depending on manager), so that you can work at home or go to appointments. As long as you have completed your contracted hours, there’s not usually a problem.

The Learning & Development department has improved training for ‘soft skills’ over the last 3 years with the Aspire programme. Aspire offers some really great career coaching with qualified external experts along with workshops and the like. This has led to a cadre of motivated and ambitious staff…but those ambitions are quickly suppressed and these staff are let down by the rest of the company which doesn’t ‘follow through’ and nurture those ambitions. In some cases, there are no job openings, in other cases, the staff members just get given more work rather than real development.
 
Nice office space and great location for HQ (Theale).

Decent IT kit (laptop and phone).
cons:
Poor salary and benefits – Dimensions has grown quite considerably, with commensurate increases in workload, yet wages are stagnant.

Poor leadership and management – very little cohesion and partnership across directorates or departments. They don’t listen to their subordinates who are closer to the coalface, instead they bury their heads in the sand or brush things under the carpet. Managers don’t take responsibility and accountability for bad decisions but are quick to blame others, showing a severe lack of integrity.

Companywide issues of communication – not being made aware of factors/issues/changes that affect your job.

Unrealistic expectations – some managers expect you to drop everything and work on ‘their projects’. Often, they expect work (that might take hours, days or even weeks to complete) to be completed in the next 5 minutes. This lack of awareness, coupled with a ‘me, me, me’ attitude, becomes wearing, exhausting and tedious, especially after you’ve explained the practicalities of the situation.

People who point out obvious flaws are either ignored or made to feel as though they are trouble makers.

Lots of pointless bureaucracy and endless meetings where very little actual work gets done.

References to training are usually referring to support worker training/qualifications (which I understand to be quite good), however, there are limited opportunities for office workers to gain qualifications and technical training (though see ‘Pros’ for soft skills training).

Staff recruitment/retention issues and significant staff shortages.

Staff are overworked and morale is low across the company. Some staff are overburdened because they are making up for poor performance by their team members as well as doing their own jobs. Some staff are incompetent and cannot do the simplest tasks and instead talk all day and accomplish very little. Some staff work inefficiently or using outdated processes, so they appear busy, but again, accomplish relatively little compared to their peers. Worse still, managers are often oblivious to the damaging effect this has on the hard-working and competent employees.

Problems persist because management is unwilling to devote resources to fixing things that were done badly/wrong in the past. New projects are also done badly because staff are stretched thin and rush through things, with few checks and balances. The issue of persistent problem also feeds back into my earlier point about pointless meetings. Too often, the same issue gets raised year in, year out because nothing has been done.

Poor processes and planning – going from one disaster to the next, putting out fires that would never reach critical states if proper planning and rigorous processes were implemented.

pros: Dimensions have helped me so much with no background in care work (have had other jobs working with adults and children but not specifically care) they have helped me with training, bern very welcoming and my manager has been great with explaining things and also helping me. The work is rewarding and you feel truly valued by staff and the people we support.
